Hello Stefano,

Thanks for the kind words about our work. It would be inter=
esting to see
how K2 graphs perform on the suite of test problems in our pa=
per. Our code
is posted in case you want to try it out. If you do, please l=
et us know
what the results are.  Cool that you tried to evolve the GI logo=
!

On Thu, Apr 13, 2017, 10:15 PM stefano.r.palmieri@... [neat] <
nea=
t@yahoogroups.com> wrote:

>
> [Attachment(s) <#m_-6610351573430214845_TopT=
ext> from
> stefano.r.palmieri@... [neat] included below]
>
> Hey Jef=
f,
>
> Thorough and great paper that touched on many important topics.
>
> =
Not to hijack here but I think K^2 Graphs could also potentially be
> anoth=
er solution to solving the problem of increasing irregularity. You can
> th=
ink of them kind of like a Quad-tree or Oct-tree where finer and finer
> de=
tail can be added, except a graph structure is used like with HyperNEAT.
> =
This naturally allows for both direct and indirect encodings.
>
> I haven't=
 implemented anything quite like the target weights task yet but
> I did tr=
y evolving the old GI logo a while back with an early
> implementation of t=
he K^2 Graph. The logo has quite a bit or irregularity
> (because it's a ci=
rcular shape), yet the K^2 does reasonably well. If you
> look closely, you=
 can see some module reuse too.
> 
>
-- 

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

(Compos=
ed via voice recognition AI: please forgive all typos)

--94eb2c03102ce9f658054d25655f

<p dir=3D"ltr">Hello Stefano, </p>
<p dir=3D"ltr">Thanks for the kind words=
 about our work. It would be interesting to see how K2 graphs perform on th=
e suite of test problems in our paper. Our code is posted in case you want =
to try it out. If you do, please let us know what the results are.=C2=A0 Co=
ol that you tried to evolve the GI logo! </p>

        <span style=3D"font-weight:700;font-size:12px;display:block;mar=
gin-bottom:20px">[<a style=3D"text-decoration:none" href=3D"#m_-66103515734=

ri@..." target=3D"_blank">stefano.r.palmieri@...</a> [neat] inc=
luded below]</span>
        
      
      <p>Hey Jeff,<br><br>Thorough and =
great paper that touched on many important topics.<br><br>Not to hijack her=
e but I think K^2 Graphs could also potentially be another solution to solv=
ing the problem of increasing irregularity. You can think of them kind of l=
ike a Quad-tree or Oct-tree where finer and finer detail can be added, exce=
pt a graph structure is used like with HyperNEAT. This naturally allows for=
 both direct and indirect encodings.<br><br>I haven't implemented anyth=
ing quite like the target weights task yet but I did try evolving the old G=
I logo a while back with an early implementation of the K^2 Graph. The logo=
 has quite a bit or irregularity (because it's a circular shape), yet t=
he K^2 does reasonably well. If you look closely, you can see some module r=
euse too.</p>

    </div>
     

    
    <div style=3D"color:#fff;height:0=
"></div>


</div>
